{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3559690,"name":"Guilherme Samuel","username":"megarubber","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/megarubber/{size}/172063_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-17T20:12:35.896Z","cooked":"

My team prepared a Raspberry Pi 5 to get PhotonVision data to roboRIO. I used a REV Mini Power Module + 5 Amp breaker (connected on PDP), with a XL4015E1 5V 5A step-down regulator and a USB-C connector, to use the max potential of coprocessor and to avoid problems related with power supply. Anyway, when I turn on the full robot control system, the Pi show a solid red color and it doesn’t boot PhotonVision and its system. How could I use Pi 5 inside robot system? Since I have not found how to wire it correctly.

Are you sure that the regulator provides enough power? We had this happen with a regulator which provided 5A through only one of the usb ports and other ports were limited with lower currents.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":4,"updated_at":"2025-03-18T13:18:55.669Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":33,"readers_count":32,"score":11.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495945,"topic_slug":"raspberry-pi-5-doesnt-boot","display_username":"Mert Ata BABER","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52778,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/raspberry-pi-5-doesnt-boot/495945/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3560477,"name":"Guilherme Samuel","username":"megarubber","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/megarubber/{size}/172063_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-18T13:38:30.062Z","cooked":"
BABER:

Are you sure that the regulator provides enough power?

Yes, I am. I short-circuited it and regulated it with the potentiometer, and the output is around 4.9A~5A, and these results are the maximum current of regulator. I think that the problem is the wire from regulator to Pi, because USB-C cables usually have a very small wire gauge. However, I don’t know how to bypass this problem.

Screenshot_20250318_102630_Chrome720×664 73.5 KB

We had an older Raspberry Pi where the USB-C connector was broken off the board. We were able to connect it to a 5V supply via the two 5V pins and some of the 8 Ground pins on the 40-pin header.

https://learn.sparkfun.com/tutorials/raspberry-gpio/gpio-pinout
